intro: Ophrys fuciflora var. coronifera, commonly known as the crown orchid, is a rare and specialized orchid species native to the mountainous regions of southern Europe. It is characterized by its unique floral structure, which includes a complex, bee-mimicking flower that plays a crucial role in its pollination strategy. The plant typically grows in calcareous soils and is adapted to cool, moist environments. Its leaves are broad and grass-like, and it produces small, greenish-yellow flowers that bloom in late spring. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a vulnerable species in its native range.
